docs.lead_paragraph: Babies who sleep on their backs, a recommended position to combat sudden infant death syndrome, or SIDS, may not crawl or move around as soon as others, according to a study published today. But, said the researchers, they soon catch up. Doctors who reported the finding recommended that infants be placed on their stomachs or sides when awake to compensate for the slight lag in developing upper body strength that appears to accompany back sleeping. The report, published in this month's issue of Pediatrics, the journal of the American Academy of Pediatrics, covered 350 healthy babies who were followed from birth until the time they walked.

headline.main: Babies' Sleeping Positions May Affect Their Mobility

docs.abstract: Study finds that babies who sleep on their backs, recommended position to combat sudden infant death syndrome, may not crawl or move around as soon as others, although they soon catch up (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is midafternoon on the eastern coast of a chronically sleep-deprived nation and if you listen carefully, you can hear the whoosh of cappuccino makers and the ripping open of No-Doz boxes and the yawns of night-shift workers and the sighs of pilots as they check their watches to see how much longer they must keep their aircraft aloft. These are the sounds of the struggle to stay awake, a major enterprise in a country that long ago exchanged the effortless biological cycle of sleeping and waking for the tyranny of electric lights, job-plus-kids living, graveyard shifts and packages that absolutely, positively have to be there overnight.

headline.main: New Hope for the Losers in the Battle to Stay Awake

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration will decide by Dec 31 whether to approve a new compound, modafinil, as treatment for excessive sleepiness associated with narcolepsy; approval of drug, which is licensed to Cephalon Inc and would be marketed as Provigil, would open door to 'off-label' use, allowing doctors to prescirbe it for other conditions, such as jet lag and sleep apnea; drug may also may help researchers unlock the mysteries of sleep and waking; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is called pilates, and I had been hearing about it for some time but dismissed it as a faddish 90's workout. It fit the mold perfectly: It had the requisite exotic name (pronounced puh-LAH-tees), you had to go to a gym to do it, and celebrities hailed it as a miracle workout that managed, with perfect 90's perversity, to give shapely women the bodies of 12-year-old boys. Pilates, I had heard, involved archaic equipment with names like ''the reformer'' and ''the barrel,'' but that was about all I knew when I arrived at TriBeCa Bodyworks, a Pilates studio on Duane Street, determined to see if my bias was well-founded. A model-thin woman blew by me, a single line of sweat dripping down her radiant cheek. Great. I hated the place already.

headline.main: Learning Pilates, One Stretch at a Time

docs.lead_paragraph: Depression among older people is an often unrecognized and untreated problem that can tarnish the golden years for millions of people who might otherwise find joy, not anguish, in their old age. That includes older people in nursing homes as well as those living independently. Experts estimate that as many as 90 percent of depressed elderly Americans are not being treated. More than five million Americans age 65 and older -- nearly one in six -- suffer from serious, persistent symptoms of depression, and another one million have major clinical depression, an immobilizing disorder that can lead to suicide. From 1980 to 1992, suicide rates rose by 9 percent among all Americans 65 and older and by 35 percent among those aged 80 to 84. Only a small percentage of those deaths are believed to represent a calculated escape from an incurable, incapacitating illness.

headline.main: Keeping Clinical Depression Out of the Aging Formula

docs.lead_paragraph: On my desk at the hospital sits a computer terminal I use to check my patients' blood tests and X-ray results. I could also, were I so inclined, use it to browse through the blood tests and X-rays of thousands of complete strangers, tracking biopsy results, guessing at life expectancies and generally shattering every known code of medical privacy and confidentiality to smithereens without ever leaving my chair. The fact that no activity could tempt me less is actually not very important. My very ordinary access code and password into an ordinary hospital computer network are just one more indication that medical privacy as we once understood it has become a thing of the past.

headline.main: Ever Elusive, Privacy Slips From Grasp Of Patients

docs.abstract: Dr Abigal Zuger article laments decline of privacy as medical patient information is increasingly stored in computer files, to which too many other people now have easy access; contrasts situation with that of 30 years ago, when medical records were almost as sacrosanct as the body itself; some experts fear that laws to protect patient privacy will come far too late (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Heels are out, athletic shoes are in, at least among teen-age girls. And orthopedic researchers believe that this trend may explain why young women have fewer foot problems than their older counterparts. A survey of 672 girls ages 10 to 18 conducted by Dr. Carol C. Frey, director of the Orthopedic Foot and Ankle Center at Los Angeles Orthopedic Hospital, found that 68 percent wore sneakers or athletic shoes most often and only 4 percent wore heels. Only 13 percent complained of foot pain and 9 percent reported foot deformities, compared with 80 percent and 76 percent reported by women ages 20 to 60 in a previous study. Both problems, said Dr. Frey, are associated with shoes that fit poorly.

headline.main: For Foot Care Tips, Don't Ask Mama

docs.abstract: Orthopedic researchers believe fact that teen-age girls wear athletic shoes and not heels may explain why younger women have fewer foot problems than their older counterparts; illus (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: An infomercial for Bodyblade, a 4-foot by 1.75-inch blade with a rubber hand grip at the center, hit the airways earlier this year, its makers hoping to follow in the lucrative footsteps of fitness products like ab rollers and butt blasters. The infomercial, which claimed that Bodyblade offered ''a complete and total body workout in as little as six minutes a day,'' enticed fitness buffs to snap up 100,000 of the $99 gadgets. But the American Council on Exercise, a watchdog for the fitness industry, disputed Bodyblade's claims. A product review, published in ACE Fitness Matters, states that performing the suggested Super Six routine -- a set of six, one-minute exercises -- offers little fitness benefit. The review, conducted by biomechanists at California State University, Northridge, said the limited movement required for most of the exercises did little to improve flexibility or strength and that no exercise device could bring about significant weight loss or increases in cardiovascular endurance if used for only six minutes a day. The reviewers also said that using Bodyblade regularly might result in overuse injuries of the shoulders and wrists.

headline.main: A Muscle Builder Or Purse Shrinker?

docs.abstract: American Council on Exercise disputes claim by makers of Bodyblade that their device, 4-foot by 1.75-inch blade with rubber handgrip sold through infomercials, offers 'complete and total body workout in as little as six minutes a day,' at $99 a unit; says using Bodyblade offers little fitness benefit and could harm shoulders and wrists; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sharon McCormack of White Salmon, Wash., loved windsurfing the Columbia River Gorge, but she had a problem on the big jumps: Her contact lenses washed out. ''Or I got dust under a lens,'' she said. ''That's incredibly painful.'' Ms. McCormack solved the problem by having laser surgery to correct her nearsightedness. More than 400,000 laser vision procedures will be done this year, industry sources say, most of them for nearsightedness, or myopia, like Ms. McCormack's. But next year, farsighted surfers and others may be having laser surgery, too.

headline.main: Lasers May Soon Be Used to Treat Farsightedness

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration may approve laser treatment for farsightedness by year's end; photo; drawings illustrate conditions of nearsightedness, or myopia, and farsightedness, or hyperopia; and how lasers can correct conditions (M)
